comments.text: That is the stylesheet which is integral information to the page -- according to the HTML specification we have to load it. It is equivalent to if the page had an -- we'd try to load that remotely, too. Looks like you saved this content from the internet. In Firefox you can save pages as "HTML Only"--which leaves remote references like images and stylesheets in the page--or as "Webpage, complete" which will also save those external files locally so the file can be read entirely off-line. This is not a bug, Firefox appears to be doing what it (or any other browser) would do when presented with the given HTML locally. If you need more information please see http://support.mozilla.com/

Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 5.1; rv:2.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/4.0

Works fine for me. The content loaded immediately with out 15 seconds delay

This delay can be confirmed if your connection is configured as described.

This issue has more to do with the way FF saves pages locally.  The delay is just a very frustrating side effect of this saving process.  One option might be to decrease this time out delay for local files.  Better solution below.

When one saves a page locally, the obvious intent is to use it later for further study.  The intent is definitely not to have that page connecting to any URL for what ever reason.  

If one actually wanted to see that page online later, one could just drag the URL to a local folder and save that instead.  Or use the “Save with URL” extension.

And if one really wanted to save all the extra garbage that is on most pages these days, one has the option to save complete and have an extra folder to save along with the HTML file.

Better solution.
Since it already has the style sheet loaded when viewing online, why not, when saving locally, just imbed that style in the saved HTML file itself.  Thus providing the intended readability of the original without having to save a whole extra folder full of all kinds of garbage.

As is, FF does a pretty lousy job of just saving locally the basic content of a page.

Thanks
comments.creator: dbkh999@hotmail.com
